title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." Congress finds that the United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, with studies showing that access to high-quality prekindergarten programs leads to academic success and reduces the likelihood of negative outcomes such as grade repetition, dropout, and criminal behavior. Public spending on prekindergarten programs yields a significant return on investment through reduced need for other services. Children who attend prekindergarten have lower chances of developing drug problems, committing felonies, and going to prison. They also have higher GPAs, are more likely to attend college, but many school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. Texas missed out on significant federal funding to expand prekindergarten programs due to budget cuts in education funding. In response to education funding cuts in Texas, some local governments funded full-day prekindergarten programs after the state legislature cut $5.4 billion in education funding and eliminated $200 million in grants for prekindergarten programs. Over half of school districts with prekindergarten programs offer only part-day programs, leading to missed federal funding of up to $118.48 million for program expansion. Certain localities would benefit from direct federal funding for prekindergarten programs. The text chunk "SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS." is about a specific section related to prekindergarten development grants. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and applications must be submitted by eligible entities. To receive a grant under this Act, a State or local government entity must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education, and provide non-Federal matching funds. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity must contribute non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20% of the grant amount. This matching requirement can be met through various sources such as State funding, local funding, philanthropy, in-kind contributions, or a combination of these resources. In order to receive a grant under this Act, a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity must provide non-Federal matching funds of at least 20% of the grant amount. This can be met through State funding, local funding, philanthropy, in-kind contributions, or a combination of these resources. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing extreme financial hardship. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching funds for entities facing extreme financial hardship. Grant recipients can award subgrants to local entities for grant activities. Subgrantees must comply with grant requirements. The Secretary cannot award subgrants to entities already receiving funds. The Secretary may not award subgrants to entities already receiving funds for a program in the same fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations is set at $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible local entity" includes local educational agencies, early childhood education programs, and consortia of these entities. "Full-day" refers to a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and lasting at least 5 hours. A high-quality prekindergarten program is defined as a program that serves children aged 3 or 4, or children who turn 5 while attending the program, based on nationally recognized standards. The program must be supported by an eligible local entity and provide a full-day of at least 5 hours. The prekindergarten program must serve children aged 3 or 4, or those who turn 5 while in the program, based on national standards. Teachers must have high qualifications, including a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment, and engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program for not more than 3 years. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program for not more than 3 years. The program must maintain a maximum class size of 20 children, a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1, offer a full-day program, and provide developmentally appropriate learning environments with evidence-based curricula aligned with the State's early learning standards. The program must offer instructional staff salaries comparable to K-12 teaching staff and provide ongoing monitoring for continuous improvement. It should also offer comprehensive services for children including screenings for vision, dental, health, and development. The program offers comprehensive services for children, including screenings for vision, dental, health, and development, along with family engagement opportunities such as parent conferences and support services. The program provides comprehensive services for children, including parent conferences for input on child's development, support services like parent education, family literacy, and nutrition services with nutritious meals aligned with guidelines from the Child and Adult Care Food Program. The program includes nutrition education for children and families, coordination with local educational agencies, and physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines. The program provides high-quality professional development, physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines, and additional support services based on needs analysis. Services are provided on-site to the maximum extent feasible. The program provides high-quality professional development for staff, on-site support services based on needs analysis, meets education performance standards, and maintains evidence-based health and safety standards. The program ensures high-quality professional development for staff, on-site support services, meets education performance standards, and maintains evidence-based health and safety standards. The terms "local educational agency" and "State" are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
